thread.title: Tamil school has CNY celebration despite no Chinese pupils
thread.title_full: Tamil school has CNY celebration despite no Chinese pupils

title: Tamil school has CNY celebration despite no Chinese pupils
text:
Saturday, 18 February 2017 Tamil school has CNY celebration despite no Chinese pupils 
A Tamil school in Tanjung Malim, Perak, held a grand Chinese New Year celebration to promote understanding and racial unity despite not having any Chinese pupils, Makkal Osai reported. 
SJK(T) Ladang Katoyang is an estate primary school with about 30 pupils and seven teachers. 
The teachers felt it was important for the pupils to appreciate the culture of other races and decided to hold a celebration as a learning opportunity, headmistress Jamila Chinnakkannu said. 
The event was also supported by parents who told their children to wear red clothes. 
The event included games, quizzes and a yee sang meal. A lion dance troupe was also present to entertain the crowd. 
> Twenty-two members have been appointed as registrars to assist in registering new Indian voters in Selangor, the daily quoted state MIC secretary S. Ravi as saying. 
The party was given approval following a request by party president Datuk Seri Dr S. Subramaniam. 
The registration of new Indian voters had lagged in recent times and that the party felt it was important to revive the process, Ravi said after the appointment ceremony. 
> Found in translation is compiled from the vernacular newspapers (Bahasa Malaysia, Chinese and Tamil dailies). As such, stories are grouped according to the respective language/medium. Where a paragraph begins with a >, it denotes a separate news item.
